G.L. c. 208, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition:
Now comes the Plaintiff, Jessica Sullivan, pursuant to G.L. c. 208, �����������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������,
and respectfully petitions this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody order dated September 15, 2021, concerning the minor child of the parties, Ethan Thompson, aged 8 years old.

G.L. c. 209C, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u.proposition: This Honorable Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 209C, ������������������������������������������������������������������������������ and G.L. c. 208, ��������������������������������������������������������������������������������, as the parties are residents of Massachusetts and the original judgment was issued by the Bristol County Probate and Family Court.

G.L. c. 208, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: Since the entry of the original order, a material change in circumstances has arisen such that the current custody arrangement is no longer in Ethan��������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������'s best interest as required under G.L. c. 208, ����������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: It is in the best interest of the minor child that modifications be made to the existing custody arrangement to address these concerns and to ensure that Ethan is provided a safe and healthy environment consistent with G.L. c. 208, ������������������������������������������������������������������������������ and the principles articulated in *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns modifying custody in the child’s best interests to ensure a safe and healthy environment under G.L. c. 208, § 31 and principles from Hunter v. Rose. Hunter squarely applies the G.L. c. 208, § 31 best-interests standard and affirms a custody award based on factors such as stability, sibling relationships, and one parent’s attempts to alienate the child from the other, explicitly framing the inquiry around the child’s welfare and living conditions. Thus, it supports citing the case for the general principle that custody arrangements should be modified/structured to protect the child’s best interests and well-being.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is ‘best for the child’…. The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31. Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent.”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The Plaintiff�����������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������'s request is supported by Massachusetts law recognizing that custody orders must be based on the best interest of the child, and where a material change in circumstances has occurred, modification is warranted to serve those interests.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The case clearly affirms that custody-related removal decisions under G.L. c. 208, § 30 must be based on the best interests of the child, which is consistent with part of the proposition. However, the opinion does not frame the dispute as a post‑judgment custody modification premised on a generic “material change in circumstances” standard, nor does it say that any material change automatically warrants modification; instead it treats relocation as governed specifically by the statutory ‘cause shown’/best‑interests analysis. Thus the case only partially supports the proposition and does not clearly support the broader ‘material change warrants modification’ language.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents…shall not … be removed out of this Commonwealth…without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ … ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ … we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: The Plaintiff������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������'s request is supported by Massachusetts law recognizing that custody orders must be based on the best interest of the child, and where a material change in circumstances has occurred, modification is warranted to serve those interests.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly affirms that custody determinations must be based on the welfare/best interests of the child and that all relevant factors must be weighed. However, it does not address modification standards or the requirement of a material change in circumstances; it is reviewing the adequacy of findings supporting an original custody award. Thus, it supports only the best‑interest component of the proposition, not the material‑change‑in‑circumstances aspect, so the full claimed proposition is not accurately supported.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied). … This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. … The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

*Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619 (2000.proposition: The Plaintiff������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������'s request is supported by Massachusetts law recognizing that custody orders must be based on the best interest of the child, and where a material change in circumstances has occurred, modification is warranted to serve those interests.
*Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619 (2000.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns Massachusetts law on modification of custody orders upon a material change in circumstances and the requirement that custody be based on the best interests of the child. Williams v. Massa is a divorce and property division case in which the SJC addresses an initial custody arrangement and corrects the procedure the judge used for potential future custody changes, holding that any change must proceed by complaint for modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28. The opinion does not articulate or apply the standard for modifying custody based on a ‘material change in circumstances,’ nor does it analyze when modification is warranted; it only says the proper procedural vehicle is a complaint for modification and briefly references best interests in passing. Thus, it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
*Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619 (2000.relevant_excerpt: “A change in a custody judgment, however, should be made pursuant to a complaint for modification under G. L. c. 208, § 28. If the judge felt that joint legal custody put the children at risk, or was not in their best interests, because of the wife’s worrisome parenting behavior, then the judge should have ordered sole legal custody to the father. She did not have discretion to fashion, even with the agreement of both parents, an alternative plan.”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: The Plaintiff������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������'s request is supported by Massachusetts law recognizing that custody orders must be based on the best interest of the child, and where a material change in circumstances has occurred, modification is warranted to serve those interests.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly affirms that custody determinations must be based on the best interests of the child, but it does not address modification of an existing custody order based on a material change in circumstances. The case is a direct appeal from an original divorce judgment awarding custody, not a post-judgment modification proceeding, and there is no discussion of the standard for modifying custody orders when circumstances change. Thus it supports only the first half of the proposition, not the full statement as framed.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare. Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930)… ‘[T]he happiness and the welfare of the children should be the controlling consideration. It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the children in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future, and it is a subject peculiarly within the discretion of the judge.’”

*C.M. v. M.M.*, 72 Mass. App. Ct. 206 (2.proposition: The Plaintiff������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������'s request is supported by Massachusetts law recognizing that custody orders must be based on the best interest of the child, and where a material change in circumstances has occurred, modification is warranted to serve those interests.
*C.M. v. M.M.*, 72 Mass. App. Ct. 206 (2.case_name: Fecteau Benefits Group, Inc. v. Knox
*C.M. v. M.M.*, 72 Mass. App. Ct. 206 (2.support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is not C.M. v. M.M., 72 Mass. App. Ct. 206 (2008), but a commercial contract case involving Fecteau Benefits Group and Knox about breach of contract, damages, and enforcement of an attorney’s fees settlement. It does not involve custody, family law, or the best interests of the child standard, nor does it discuss modification of custody orders based on a material change in circumstances. Therefore it cannot support the proposition regarding Massachusetts custody law and modification standards.
*C.M. v. M.M.*, 72 Mass. App. Ct. 206 (2.relevant_excerpt: “On June 17, 2002, Fecteau Benefits Group, Inc. (FBG), brought a complaint in the Superior Court against Peter L. Knox and Peter L. Knox & Associates (collectively, Knox), alleging breach of contract, breach of the implied covenant of good faith, intentional interference with an advantageous business relationship, fraud, and a violation of G. L. c. 93A, arising out of FBG’s acquisition of Knox’s pension administration business.”

*Sherman v. Sherman*, 480 Mass. 804 (201.proposition: The Plaintiff������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������'s request is supported by Massachusetts law recognizing that custody orders must be based on the best interest of the child, and where a material change in circumstances has occurred, modification is warranted to serve those interests.
*Sherman v. Sherman*, 480 Mass. 804 (201.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt is a Massachusetts criminal homicide case dealing with evidentiary issues, police investigation adequacy, identification procedures, confrontation rights, ineffective assistance, and new trial standards. It does not involve family law, custody determinations, or modification of custody based on a material change in circumstances or the best interests of the child. Therefore, it provides no authority for the cited custody-related proposition and appears to be an entirely inapposite citation, likely a miscitation or placeholder error.
*Sherman v. Sherman*, 480 Mass. 804 (201.relevant_excerpt: Because the defendant was convicted of murder in the first degree, "[r]ather than evaluating an ineffective assistance claim under the traditional standard of Commonwealth v. Saferian ... we apply the more favorable standard of G. L. c. 278, § 33E, to determine whether there was a substantial likelihood of a miscarriage of justice." ... Having carefully reviewed the defendant's arguments pursuant to our duty under G. L. c. 278, § 33E, we conclude that the defendant is not entitled to relief.
